chunks.chunk_text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil. And I'm Beth. Would you like some fried chicken and chips with gravy, Beth? No thanks, Neil. I don't really like fried chicken. It's too oily for me. OK, no problem. But maybe you'd like some organic poulet rotti in a tendermeat jus with frites. Oh, that sounds interesting.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: Well, it's French for chicken and chips with gravy. It's a strange fact, but the same dish described using different words can make it sound more delicious, more exotic and more desirable. Restaurants think carefully about the language they use to describe the food on their menus, trying to make it sound appealing, tasty or poetic. Instead of hamburgers, we have gourmet burgers. It's jus, not gravy, and raspberry coulis,
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: sounds a lot tastier than raspberry sauce. Many of the words used to describe gourmet food – that's food which is higher quality and more sophisticated than usual – are French, coming from a country with a long tradition of high-level cooking called haute cuisine. But how does the language used to describe food affect our psychology and help restaurants make menus which are both tempting and profitable? That's what we'll be finding out in this programme, along with
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: some useful new vocabulary as well. But first, I have a question for you, Neil. To train as a classical French chef takes months as a full-time apprentice. But what is the name of the most famous cooking school teaching French haute cuisine? Is it… Well, I think it's Le Cordon Bleu. OK, Neil. I'll reveal the correct answer later.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: It's important for restaurants to describe items on the menu so diners know what to expect. And many chefs think foreign words sound more exciting. But according to linguist Dr Kerry Matwick, the use of French is decreasing. Here, Kerry explains why to Ruth Alexander, presenter of BBC World Service programme The Food Chain.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: Many restaurants use French names in menus because they sound fancy – an adjective meaning special or unusual, with lots of decoration. Kerry disagrees. She thinks French names used to be popular but are now seen as pretentious. If something is pretentious,
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: it tries to appear more important or clever than it really is. Brazilian chef Caroline Martins agrees that using French names in menus is becoming a thing of the past. Caroline has stopped using French names in her pop-up restaurant Sampa in Manchester, as she explained to Ruth Alexander
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: of BBC World Service programme The Food Chain.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: Instead of feeling excited about dishes described in French, Caroline's diners were sarcastic about them. They mocked and made fun of them. Some diners even walked out.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: Too fashionable, expensive and not available to everyone. She's now started using English and her native Brazilian Portuguese on the menu and is pleased with the results. Customers don't feel confused and their curiosity about the Brazilian dishes starts a conversation with the waiter. All this talk of food is making me hungry, Neil. Anyway, it's time to reveal the answer to my question. What's the name of the famous French cooking school that teaches haute cuisine?
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: I said it was Le Cordon Bleu. Was I right? Le Cordon Bleu was the correct answer. The famous culinary arts school Le Cordon Bleu first opened its doors in Paris in 1895. OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learnt from this programme, starting with gourmet food. Food which is better quality and more sophisticated than usual and is often more expensive. The adjective fancy means special, unusual and decorative.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: If someone is pretentious, they try to appear more important or clever than they really are. The phrase to turn someone off means to make someone stop feeling interested or excited. If you say something sarcastic, you mock and insult something by saying the opposite of what you mean. And finally, the adjective posh means fashionable, smart, expensive and exclusive. Once again, our six minutes are up. Join us again soon for more trending
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_How the language of menus matters.json

chunks.chunk_text: topics and useful vocabulary here at 6 Minute English. Goodbye for now. Bye.
